image.altText: Man in a black shirt and grey hoodie standing outside.

items.synopsis: Aiden Aslin survived five months of torture in Russian captivity. Now free, he wants to share the story of one Ukrainian man who didn't make it out alive. WARNING: Some readers may find the details of this story distressing.

title.children: Aiden thought his Russian captors could stoop no lower as they tortured him. Then they got a camera out

image.altText: Two men in army uniform smile.

items.synopsis: Former navy clearance divers tell the Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide how they didn't receive support from the Australian Defence Force following a confronting shark attack in Sydney Harbour in 2009. WARNING: This story contains graphic details.

title.children: Navy divers criticise 'head in the sand' ADF culture at royal commission after graphic details emerge about shark attack

image.altText: Sam Kerr

items.synopsis: From Sam Kerr's shock injury to New Zealand's moment of ecstasy, these are the five talking points from the opening day of the Women's World Cup.

title.children: Five quick hits — Sam Kerr injury leaves worrying hole for Matildas and NZ lethargy turns to ecstasy

image.altText: A colour photograph from the 1980s of a swimming carnival at the Glenorchy pool

items.synopsis: All three of Hobart's public 50m swimming pools used to be outside, but the only one left won't open this summer — and could close permanently.

title.children: 'I remember snow being around the outside': Fond memories of Hobart's last outdoor public pool

image.altText: Mitchell Starc grimaces as he holds his shoulder as Pat Cummins looks disappointed next to him

items.synopsis: Day two at Old Trafford is Australia's worst of this Ashes series by far, as England takes complete control of the fourth Test and leaves the tourists fighting for their lives.

title.children: Australia's wheels fall off on day two at Old Trafford, leaving a fight for its Ashes life

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff gestures while speaking in parliament.

items.synopsis: Jeremy Rockliff announces he is stepping down as health minister, while reminding two rogue MPs they were elected as Liberals, not independents.

title.children: 'They were elected on our team': Tasmanian premier issues stern reminder to rogue MPs

image.altText: A melting ice sheet.

items.synopsis: An ice core discovered at a secret US Army base may rewrite the history of Greenland ice sheet melting, pointing to rapid ice loss and sea level rise after relatively small historical warming.

title.children: A secret plan to hide nuclear weapons under ice in the 1960s could change our understanding of sea level rise

image.altText: A black and white photo of a Chinese navy ship.

items.synopsis: Officials are preparing for two Chinese spy ships to arrive off Australia's coast next week to monitor the multinational Talisman Sabre military exercises opening in Sydney this morning.

title.children: Chinese spy ships expected off NT and Queensland during Talisman Sabre military exercises

image.altText: Two men wearing bright orange vests inspect a piece of machinery.

items.synopsis: Australia's buoyant jobs market is so far easily absorbing a record migrant intake, with many employers turning to retirees to fill vacant positions.

title.children: Retirees lured back to work as employers continue to face tight labour market

image.altText: Aerial shot of the Liddell coal-fired power plant surrounded by lake and green fields

items.synopsis: After benchmark power prices jumped hundreds of dollars a year, a senior energy researcher questions whether households will end up paying too much.

title.children: 'Striking' falls in wholesale prices spark claims consumers are paying too much for power

image.altText: A woman looks at a pair of Japanese shoes

items.synopsis: Japan's sole custody laws have long been criticised for incentivising child abduction, but the system may be about to change, with Australia playing a key role behind the scenes.

title.children: Joint custody doesn't exist in Japan. For many parents, their children vanish

image.altText: A drone picture showing part of Richmond, with high-rise public housing towers in the foreground and a city skyline behind.

items.synopsis: One capital city continues to lead the charge, while only one city records falling prices, as Australia's housing values increase.

title.children: Which Australian capital cities recorded the biggest gains and losses in values?

image.altText: Three views of the birthday cake clock, with the uncleaned original centre.

items.synopsis: A milk crate full of old metal trash turns out to be a historic artefact — but it nearly went to the dump.

title.children: Garden shed clean-out turns up birthday cake clock worth $48,000

image.altText: Dozens on UK flags wave at King Charles walking down a lane

items.synopsis: More than 86 million pounds went towards running the British royal households and paying for travel expenses in 2022.

title.children: British royal family's funding cut back

image.altText: Education Minister Jason Clare wearing a suit and speaking at the National Press Club.

items.synopsis: The university sector reforms announced this week have been warmly received, but much tougher decisions lie ahead, and it's almost guaranteed some will be left bitterly disappointed, national education and parenting reporter Conor Duffy writes.

title.children: The education minister floated 'spiky' ideas for university reform. Some are already leaving a sting

image.altText: A close-up picture of Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews looking thoughtful.

items.synopsis: From tearing up the East West Link contract at a cost of more than a billion dollars, to cancelling the Commonwealth Games this week, the Andrews government is no stranger to budget blowouts. Analysts say the scale of projects and underestimating costs may be part of the problem.

title.children: Calls for greater transparency as Andrews government's project cost blowouts stack up

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks towards Annastacia Palaszczuk at a press confernece

items.synopsis: Andrew Leigh won't have made himself many friends in Labor with his attack this week on the stifling power of the party's factions, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: How much do we know about what goes on behind the scenes of the Albanese government?

image.altText: Flashing lights of ambulance, fire and police vehicles on a road littered with debris.

items.synopsis: Police say a stolen car was involved in a three-vehicle crash that killed three people on the Bruce Highway at Federal, between the Sunshine Coast and Gympie.

title.children: Three people killed in Bruce Highway crash allegedly involving stolen car

image.altText: An AI microscope scans slides of human blood tests at Sullivan Nicolaides Pathology

items.synopsis: Next time you get a blood test, a robot using artificial intelligence could be the one to scan it for infections.

title.children: Queensland claims 'world first' in medical artificial intelligence with new tech detecting diseases in blood

image.altText: The Matildas celebrate by running towards each other near the goal.

items.synopsis: The Matildas have defeated the Republic of Ireland 1-0 in their World Cup opener on home soil after losing captain Sam Kerr to a calf injury.

title.children: Matildas defeat Ireland in World Cup opener after losing Kerr pre-game

image.altText: several southern calamari floating underwater

items.synopsis: Fried calamari rings? You may want to think twice — the Tasmanian government is proposing a reduction in the number of calamari fishery licenses.

title.children: Tasmanian government proposes changes to calamari fishery in response to depleting stocks

image.altText: A soccer player wearing yellow and green kicks the ball during a game with opponents wearing green and white behind her

items.synopsis: Australia's stand-in captain didn't expect to take a penalty, but Steph Catley's maturity reflects a team who navigated their unexpected World Cup opener.

title.children: How Steph Catley's coolness allowed the Matildas to manage their World Cup moment

image.altText: Composite image of four people in grayscale layered on top of each other with an Aboriginal flag in the background.

items.synopsis: Aboriginal executives across Australia advise people on First Nations' issues every day. They explain how an Indigenous Voice to Parliament could work just as they do.

title.children: The Voice is not a new concept. Meet the people that act as a 'Voice' in their communities

image.altText: Zak Crawley holds his bat and helmet aloft and smiles

items.synopsis: England powers its way into a position from which it can level the Ashes series, with Zak Crawley's dominant century putting the hosts in front on day two of the fourth Test at Old Trafford.

title.children: Zak Crawley's blistering ton gives England first-innings lead on day two of Old Trafford Test

image.altText: Pat Cummins lies on the floor

items.synopsis: Australia has a day to forget at Old Trafford as Pat Cummins shells chances, Mitchell Starc injures his shoulder and Zak Crawley scores a magnificent century. Here are five things you missed from day two of the fourth Test.

title.children: Five quick hits — Cummins gets out first ball of the day and Starc battles with an injured shoulder

image.altText: A well dressed woman arrives at court

items.synopsis: Helen Mary Rosamond embezzled millions from the NAB to fund a life of opulence between 2013 and 2017, including luxury holidays, business-class flights, and a 50th birthday party that cost $70,000.

title.children: 'Breathtaking in its audacity': Woman who embezzled millions from NAB jailed for 15 years

image.altText: A woman with brown short hair sits behind a microphone

items.synopsis: The senior bureaucrat who oversaw the rollout of the Robodebt scheme is suspended without pay after the royal commission found she did "nothing of substance" after discovering illegalities.

title.children: Top bureaucrat behind Robodebt suspended from $900k job

image.altText: A white man with light brown hair and wearing a grey 40s suit, stands in a windswept and gloomy desert landscape.

items.synopsis: Christopher Nolan’s masterful movie fuses spectacle and melancholy to tell the true story of J Robert Oppenheimer, who oversaw the creation of the atomic bomb and changed the course of history.

title.children: Why Oppenheimer is the film you should go and see this week

image.altText: Protesters scale a wall.

items.synopsis: Iraq asks Sweden's ambassador to leave amid fiery protests over a planned Koran burning at the Iraqi embassy in Stockholm.

title.children: Iraq expels Swedish ambassador after man desecrates Koran in Stockholm

image.altText: Rescuers work at a site of a building heavily damaged by a Russian missile attack.

items.synopsis: A Chinese consular building is damaged in a third successive night of air strikes on southern Ukrainian port cities, Ukrainian officials say.

title.children: Chinese consulate damaged in Russian attack on Ukraine's Odesa

image.altText: A police officer stands in front of a police car.

items.synopsis: New Zealand police say the 24-year-old had no licence for the shotgun he used to carry out the attack, and that he had a history of family violence.

title.children: Man who killed two at Auckland construction site had no gun licence, NZ police confirm

image.altText: A glass pipe, used for smoking the drug ice, sits on a bench.

items.synopsis: A Cooma man who stabbed his friend more than 15 times during a paranoid drug-fuelled rage on an isolated Snowy Mountains road in 2021, has been sentenced to 24 years behind bars for his murder.

title.children: Court hears of horrific final moments of man’s life before 'brutal' murder by laughing, meth-crazed killer

image.altText: A black and white image of Ronald Reagan reclining in his seat.

items.synopsis: Reagan is the only union leader to serve as US President. Paradoxically, he was also one of the most aggressively anti-union presidents of the 20th century.

title.children: How Ronald Reagan led the 1960 actors' strike – and then became an anti-union president

image.altText: tillies jump

items.synopsis: The Matildas ground out a 1-0 win over Ireland to start their home Women's World Cup campaign, and the internet was in agony.

title.children: 'This team will be the end of me': How the internet reacted to the Matildas' 1-0 win over Ireland
